title: How to Paint an Interior Door

steps.headline: Clean the space where you will paint the door.
steps.description: Sweep the floors and make sure any dust and dirt is gone. You don’t want anything sticking to the wet paint and ruining your paint job. Make sure you will be painting in a well-ventilated area. Put drop clothes or cardboard on the floor to protect it from spilled paint.

steps.headline: Remove the door from the wall.
steps.description: Have someone help you with this task by holding the door as you remove the hinge pins with a flat screwdriver by pressing up lightly. Then unscrew the hinges with a screwdriver or drill. Place the door on sawhorses or on the floor.

steps.headline: Leave the door on its hinges if it is a flat door.
steps.description: You can also leave a paneled door on its hinges, though it might result in more paint runs than laying the door flat. Leaving on its hinges makes it possible to paint both sides of the door at once, instead of waiting for it to dry and then flipping it.

steps.headline: Clean the door with a liquid deglosser and a rag.
steps.description: If the door is dusty, dirty, or greasy, the paint won’t stick as well. Focus especially on cleaning around the door knob. After you’ve wiped down the door, wipe it dry with a clean rag. Wear rubber gloves when handling deglossers, primers, and paint. One cleaner you could use is TSP (trisodium phosphate), which is a powder you dissolve in warm water.

steps.headline: Protect the door hinges and knobs.
steps.description: You can either remove them, or cover them with rubber cement or tape. Make sure you keep the screws with the fixtures you have removed in a safe place, so that you'll be able to put them on again when you are done.

steps.headline: Determine if the door is painted with oil-based or latex paint.
steps.description: Rub a little rubbing alcohol onto the door, and if the paint comes off, it is latex. If it’s latex you can skip the following sanding and priming steps, though you’ll have to sand and prime if the paint is oil-based.

steps.headline: Sand the door lightly using fine grit sandpaper or sanding block.
steps.description: You don’t need to use a power sander. Make sure to sand the entire door to create a smooth, even surface. Remove any sawdust with a damp rag.

steps.headline: Paint the door with an oil-based primer.
steps.description: Paint the counters of the door with primer first, and then use a roller for the flat surfaces. Let the primer dry before painting. Your primer should be a similar shade to the final paint color. Make sure to use interior primer for your interior door.

steps.headline: Sand the door again once the primer has dried.
steps.description: Drying the primer could take 1-3 hours, and maybe even longer if you are in a humid place. Sand lightly and evenly, just like the first time. Wipe off the door with a damp cloth to remove any sawdust and let the door dry again before painting.

steps.headline: Stir your paint and pour it into a roller tray.
steps.description: Paint cans are usually pretty clearly marked if they are for exterior or interior use, so make sure you have interior paint before beginning. Stir the paint well using a stirring stick until it’s not separated and doesn't have lumps.

steps.headline: Use a 9-inch roller to paint the whole door if it doesn’t have panels.
steps.description: Mix the paint with a stirring stick and pour it into a roller tray. Roll with long, even strokes. Be sure to paint in the same direction as the wood grain. Paint the edges of the door last.

steps.headline: Paint the recessed panels, the horizontal rails and then the vertical stiles if the door has panels.
steps.description: Use a small roller to quickly roll on the paint. Then use a brush to smooth it out and fill in missed spots. The brush should be going in the same direction as the wood grain. Paint the edges of the door last. Smooth out any paint drips on the door with your paint brush.

steps.headline: Let the door dry and then do a second coat.
steps.description: Drying could take an hour or longer. You may have to sand between coats. Apply the second coat in the same way you did the first.

steps.headline: Paint the other side of the door using the same process.
steps.description: Once the door has dried, you'll have to put the door back on its hinges and return any hardware you removed, like doorknobs. Then you can enjoy the new, clean door that you painted yourself.
